{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox military person | name = Laurence Henry Scott | image = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1896|3|9}} | death_date = Unknown | birth_place = [[Chipping Barnet]], [[Hertfordshire]], [[England]] | death_place = | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial = | placeofburial_coordinates = | nickname = | allegiance = United Kingdom | branch = British Army
Royal Air Force | serviceyears = 1914â€“1921 | rank = Captain | unit = [[London Regiment]]
[[Middlesex Regiment]]
[[No. 20 Squadron RAF|No. 20 Squadron RFC]] | commands = | battles = World War I
{{*}}[[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] | awards = [[Military Cross]] | relations = | laterwork = }} Captain '''Laurence Henry Scott''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|MC}} (born 9 March 1896, date of death unknown) was a British [[World War I]] [[flying ace]] credited with [[List of World War I aces credited with 6 victories|six aerial victories]].{{cite web |url=http://www.theaerodrome.com/aces/england/scott2.php |title=Laurence Henry Scott |work=The Aerodrome |year=2016 |accessdate=18 January 2016}} ==Military service== Scott first served as a [[Private (rank)|private]] in the 14th (County of London) Battalion, [[The London Regiment]] ([[London Scottish (regiment)|London Scottish]]), [[Territorial Force]], until commissioned as a [[second lieutenant]] in the 8th Battalion, [[The Duke of Cambridge's Own (Middlesex Regiment)]] on 26 February 1915.{{London Gazette |date=23 February 1915 |supp=yes |issue=29083 |startpage=1972}} On 27 September 1916 he was seconded for duty with the [[Royal Flying Corps]],{{London Gazette |date=13 October 1916 |issue=29783 |startpage=9875 |nolink=yes}} and appointed a flying officer (observer).{{London Gazette |date=13 October 1916 |issue=29783 |startpage=9863 |nolink=yes}} He was posted to [[No. 20 Squadron RAF|No. 20 Squadron RFC]] to fly with Captain [[George Reid (RAF officer)|George Reid]], as observer/gunner in a [[Royal Aircraft Factory F.E.2|F.E.2b]] fighter/reconnaissance aircraft. Between 29 July and 21 October 1916 Scott and Reid accounted for four enemy aircraft destroyed (one shared) and two driven down out of control. Scott was promoted to lieutenant on 1 November 1916,{{London Gazette |date=5 January 1917 |issue=29892 |startpage=289 |nolink=yes}} and his award of the [[Military Cross]] was gazetted soon after on 24 November. His citation read: :2nd Lt. Laurence Henry Scott, Middlesex Regiment. ::"For conspicuous gallantry in action. He and his pilot pursued a hostile aeroplane for some six miles into the enemy's territory and there shot it down. He has on many previous occasions done very fine work."{{London Gazette |date=24 November 1916 |supp=yes |issue=29837 |startpage=11544 |nolink=yes}} On 13 July 1917 Scott was appointed an assistant instructor in gunnery (graded as an equipment officer, 2nd class).{{London Gazette |date=28 August 1917 |supp=yes |issue=30257 |startpage=8969 |nolink=yes}} and on 1 January 1918 was appointed an instructor in gunnery (equipment officer, 1st class) with the acting rank of captain.{{London Gazette |date=25 February 1919 |supp=yes |issue=31202 |startpage=2808 |nolink=yes}} He was transferred to the RAF's unemployed list on 20 April 1919,{{London Gazette |date=11 July 1919 |issue=31449 |startpage=8858 |nolink=yes}} returning to serve in the 8th Battalion, Middlesex Regiment, until finally relinquishing his commission on completion of service on 1 September 1921.{{London Gazette |date=20 December 1921 |supp=yes |issue=32555 |startpage=10442 |nolink=yes}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Scott, Laurence H.}} [[Category:1896 births]] [[Category:Year of death missing]] [[Category:People from Barnet]] [[Category:London Regiment soldiers]] [[Category:Middlesex Regiment officers]] [[Category:Royal Flying Corps officers]] [[Category:Royal Air Force personnel of World War I]] [[Category:British World War I flying aces]] [[Category:Recipients of the Military Cross]]
